My thought process was basically this:
In order to optimize your solution you need the binary number with the smallest amount of digits that could represent every square on the boards. So for our standard 8x8 chessboard you need a 6 digits number, since you can represent the entire board with that. Ok, so far so good.
But in addition to that, you need enough squares in the board to represent each possible combination of 1s and 0s on that binary number. That's because you need to have total control of that number just by changing one square, so you need every possible combination at your disposal. For a 6 digits binary number that's 2 to the power of 6, or 64!
It's easy to demonstrate that any number of squares that's not a power of two wouldn't be able to "fit" every possible combination of 1s and 0s of your binary number, since that's always going to be a power of 2.

here is an algorithm I figured out for solving half of the cube corner painting problem.

Problem: paint the vertices of an n dimensional cube each one of n colors such that every vertex is connected to at least one vertex of every color.
Observation from problem statement: the color of a given vertex is irrelevant, only the colors of the surrounding vertices matter.
Assertion from observation: any vertex x must share a color with exactly one of its neighbors.
Proof of assertion: for any vertex x on an n cube, it will have n neighbors, bringing the total number of vertices connected to any given vertex, including that vertex, to n+1. Because there are only n colors to choose from, two of these vertices must be the same color. If the pair of two vertices that are the same color does not include vertex x, then x will have two neighbors of the same color which necessarily means that it does not have a neighbor of whatever color x is. By extension, this only gets worse if x shares a color with more than one neighbor.
Simplification of assertion: any vertex will have one edge which connects it to a vertex of the same color. Let us call these vertexes “share edges” because their two vertexes share a color.
Expansion of simplification of assertion: two share edges may not share a vertex (because then the shared vertex would share a color with more than one of its neighbors)
Extraction from above: therefore, all share edges must be parallel (assuming the n cube has all right angles)

Find the maximum number of unique parallel edges on the n cube (can’t think of a reason why, other than because it will do the following). Because all share edges must be parallel, they all share a dimension. Therefore, the n cube may be collapsed along that dimension, becoming an n-1 cube, painted with n colors.
The problem now becomes: paint the vertices of an n-1 cube with n colors such that no two adjacent vertices are the same color and such that any vertex x is connected to vertices of every color that x is not. (there’s probably a really clean way to write that with group theory or something but I don’t know it.)

My solution:

1. Solve it for 2:
Need a mapping from each of 00, 01, 10, and 11 to 0 and 1. My (simple) solution: parity of first bit. Changing second bit is the null operation.
Name this the 2-mapping.

2. Use solution for 2 to solve for 4:
Arrange positions in a grid: ABCD becomes
AB
CD

Now, apply the 2-mapping to the parity of the rows to indicate what row the key is on (simply change the parity of the relevant row by changing either A or B, or C or D).
Then, apply the 2-mapping to the parity of the columns to indicate what column the key is on (change A or C, or B or D).
Name this the 4-mapping.

3. Use solution for 4 to solve for 64:
Segment the 64 squares into 4 4x4 quadrants.

def parity(code):

def xor(code1, code2):
return [c1^c2 for c1, c2 in zip(code1, code2)]

def flip_which_(code, target_label):
assert 2**len(target_label)==len(code)

n = len(code)
if n==1:
return 0

part1 = code[:n//2]
part2 = code[n//2:]

xored = xor(part1, part2)

sub_flip_pos = flip_which_(xored, target_label[1:])

ishigh = parity(part1)
wanthigh = target_label[0]

n = len(code)

part1 = code[:n//2]
part2 = code[n//2:]

sub_label = decode_(xored)
if ishigh:
return [1, *sub_label]

So I haven’t watched the Hamming correction codes video precisely because I wanted to attempt this problem myself. It took my a bit over two days of pondering to come to a solution. So the first goal of problem is to find a way expressing the position of the key with the arrangement of the board. Without loss of generality, this is equivalent to finding a function that computes a number mod 64 using 64 input values mod 2. We also have the added constraint that we must be able to vary the output of the function by any n mod 64 by only changing one of the inputs. Naturally it makes sense to try and simplify this function. Since any number mod 64 is representable by a 6 length bitstring, we rewrite the function as f:Z_2^64 -> Z_2^6. The goal here is be able to choose which values in the 6 length bitstring to flip based on changing a single input value. The solution I came up with was the hypercube in R^6 formed by the Cartesian product of {0,1}^6. We assign a bit value to each point in this subspace and we label the axis x_1, x_2, x_3…, x_6. The value for the nth digit in the bit string is equivalent to the bit value at the origin plus the sum of bit values were the dot product between the position of the bitvalue and x_n is non zero. In more simple terms, for each position (a,b,c,d,e,f) the first digit of the bitstring is equivalent to the bitvalue at the origin plus the sum of all the bitvalues of positions where a =\= 0. This gives us a unique way of attaining any length 6 bitstring by just choosing which input to flip. Thus, for any original arrangement of the board, we can flip a single coin such that the function of the resulting board gives us the position of the key.

This is a really good puzzle. The choice of a chessboard is significant because it has 64 squares. But to be a truly great puzzle, all the relevant properties of a chessboard should be significant, not just the number of squares. A chessboard can be rotated 180 degrees and it will look the same. If Prisoner 2 is led into the room and he notices that the room is 180-degree symmetrical with two entrance doors, and it also so happens that the arrangement of heads and tails is similarly symmetrical (ie a palindrome when written as a sequence),  then he only has a 50% chance, no matter what he has previously discussed with Prisoner 1. There is absolutely no way to know whether he is looking at the board from the same side as Prisoner 1 was. So it's a choice between square x , and square (63-x), and those can't be the same square. So to solve the problem, Prisoner 1 would have to never leave a palindrome. He can certainly avoid leaving a palindrome, but that removes some of his options, and he doesn't have any spare options. Therefore the problem, as presented, really is impossible, after all.

I just took a class in coding theory (including Hamming Codes), so here's my solution! Grant, if you read this then please comment <3
The theory: H*e_i can be any vector in the space of the parity check matrix by the definition of H, so obviously you can pick an e_i such that H*e_i = H*L - H*x, where x is the board encoded as a word (not a codeword), e_i is a one-hot vector with a 1 at index i that denotes the single coin to flip, H*L is the location of the key (read down the vector as if it were binary), and H is the parity check matrix of the hamming code...
.
The solution:
- The player who saw the key go in the hole picks e_i according to the above, i.e. e_i such that H*e_i = H*L - H*x. If the syndrome of x is already the syndrome of L, i.e. H*L = H*x and you don't want to make a change / want e_i to just be 0, let e_i = the vector corresponding to the top left corner (or whatever square was defined to multiply the zero vector), which gets encoded as the 0 vector so there's no issue.
- The other player who needs to find where the key is decodes the location as H*x' = H*L (again, read down the vector as if it were binary), where x' is the new board after the flip.
.
The main intuition is that Hamming Codes are of size 2^r - 1, and we have 2^r squares, so if we encode the board as a number then one of the squares multiplies the zero vector. We can decide not to make a change if the board already encodes the correct location by letting e_i correspond with the square that multiplies the zero vector.

My solution, using codes, before looking at the solution in the video, goes as follows: 

The second prisoner will be confronted with a particular state of coins on a board, and he has no way of knowing which coin was flipped. 

So, in short, he needs a rule which assigns to every possible state of the board (there are 2^64 such states) a position on the board (there are 64=8x8 positions), which is the position of the key he chooses. In other words, the second prisoner needs to know a partition of the set of states, say V, into 64 subsets say V1, V2,...,V64.
Then, if the state he is confronted with is in the subset Vi, he will choose position i.

Of course, not any partition will work since we also have to take into account the actual game: the first prisoner has be able to prepare the state accordingly by just flipping a single coin, starting from an arbitrary position. In other words, the partition needs to have the property that it is possible to move from one subset Vi to another subset Vj by just flipping a single coin.

This is a remarkable and rare property of such a partition! And a remarkable property calls for a remarkable solution.

Luckily, there is an extremely pretty mathematical way of creating partitions (to fast forward: by using orbits under a group action, or by using the quotient space construction in linear algebra)! But for this, we need to actually do math, and use the nice structure of the set of states.

The set of states V is not only a plain old set, but it can be given the structure of a vector space. In particular, it is possible to define an addition on the set of states! How is this possible? First, for convenience, let us rename Heads to 0 and Tails to 1. Now, we can actually add Heads and Tails using our standard arithmetic, but with a slight twist. Clearly 0+0, and 1+0=1. The small twist is, that 1+1=0, as there is no 2 around. Now to add two states, we simply apply this rule to every of the 64 positions on the board.

For example, if our board would be much smaller (2x2) a possible addition would look like this:

1 | 0 0 | 1 1 | 1
-------- + --------- = ------------
1 | 1 0 | 1 1 | 0

So I applied the addition rule from above 4 times. Neat isn't it? The same of course works for the big 8x8 board, but it would be a lot of work to put an example in a Youtube comment. Note, that the act of flipping a coin can now be done by addition! Namely, if I want to flip the coin at position i, I can do this by adding the state which is all 0, but 1 in position I (we will can this state ei, why not). Even neater!

Now, let us first find the set C=V1, so the set of states, which would correspond to the key being in position 1 on the board.
I call this set C, since here linear codes come into play!

First, a reasonable assumption is that all the sets V1,..,Vn, should have the same size. So C should have size 2^64/64=2^64/2^5=2^58. Here we are lucky that the number of position on the board is a power of 2, hahaha!
Second, the next assumption I will make is that C is a subspace, that is, closed under addition. In other words, if I have two states in C and add them together, they should be in C again. This makes C really nice and symmetric, and also tractable for the methods of linear algebra.
Third, I will assume that the state e1=(1,0,0,0,0,0......) is in C. This will catch the annoying case that the warden puts the key in position 1 and the coins in a position already in C, but we are sill forced to flip a coin. Then we will simply flip the first coin, and stay in our subset C, haha! To specify C, which will have 2^58=A LOT, of elements, I will simply give a list of 58 elements v1,....,v58 in C, and then say: C consists of all possible sums one can form with this 58 elements (including the 0 state which is all 0). 
Fifth, the magic happens: I want to construct a C with the following property: all elements in C (apart from the state 0=(0,0,....) and e1=(1,0,0,0,...)) should have at least 3 non-zero entries. This is possible in the following way. 

First v1=e1, only 57 more to go! The next 57 states will all be of the neat form v2=e2+w2, v3=e3+w3, ...., v58=e58+w58 with the following restriction: the states w2 to w58 should be all 0 in the first 58 positions and should contain at least 2 ones in the positions 59-64. In fact, there are exactly 2^6-6-1+57 such possible states w (here again, we are so luckyyyy). So we simply take all of them, in any order we like hahaha.

Now, believe it or not, we are done. Let me explain why. So first, let me specify the other sets V_2,...V_64. So the set V_2 will be e2+C, which is simply a notation for all vector which are e2 plus some state c in C. The set V3 will be e3+C, and so on!
Second, we observe that all the sets V1,...,Vn, do not overlap. Assume that there would be such an overlap, say the state v would be in Vi and Vj. Then v=ei+c and also v=ej+d for states c and d in C. By simply manipulating this equations, we have c+d=ei+ej, so this means that ei+ej is in C. But this is impossible! We constructed C in a way that every state in C (apart from 0 and e1) has more than 2 non-zero entries.

That forces our choice of V1, V2,...V64 is indeed a partition of V.

All that is left show is that one can get from any subset to any other subset with one coin-flip. Ok, first, it is easy to get from a state in V1=C to any other set Vi, simply by flipping the coin at position i which is just the same as adding the vector ei.
Now let me also argue, that is must be possible to get from an arbitrary state in an arbitrary Vi to a state in an arbitrary Vj. First, if i=j, I simply flip coin 1 (it is easy to see that this work, think about it!). Else, I claim that there must be one flip doing the right thing. Assume that flipping the coins 2,...,64 all DO NOT bring you to the right Vj. Then, by the "pidgeonhole principle", or whatever people call this, a must 2 different positions of flips, say k and l, bringing you into the same subset Vm, for m not equal to j. In other words, ei+c+ek=ei+d+el, for some states c and d in C. This means that ek+el is in C, which is again impossible.

So we see that the solution works! It involves linear algebra, the field with two elements, codes and such, but I hope that one can still appreciate

Here is my solution using binary XOR operation
Represent a board as a 64 bit number. Bit state depends on the state of corresponding coin on the board, and is either 0 or 1. Each bit has it's index 0...63, bit index can be represented as a 6 bit integer (2**6 = 64). The bit which has a key will have index KEY.
Next we will define a "RESULT" of the board. In order to calculate RESULT, initialize RESULT with 0. Then walk through all bits in the number, and XOR bit index with RESULT if bit is set:
for (int i = 0; i < 63; i++) { if (bitSet(i) { RESULT = RESULT ^ i; } }
Now, RESULT is some arbitrary number which may or may not be equal to KEY. We need to find a bit which has to be flipped to make RESULT equal to KEY, say FLIP_INDEX
When we flip bit at FLIP_INDEX, we effectively perform a XOR operation on RESULT. KEY = RESULT ^ FLIP_INDEX.
Now, considering that if (A ^ B == C) then (A == C ^ B), we can calculate FLIP_INDEX = RESULT ^ KEY.
This gives us index of bit which we flip. After flipping that bit, RESULT of the board will be equal to KEY.
Then, second prisoner has to calculate RESULT of the board, and open the bit which index is equal to RESULT.

Solution, before watching past the first minute, but after 3h of work LOL: let the location of the key cell be indexed by a six-bit number B, spelled b_5, b_4, b_3, b_2, b_1, b_0. Let the chessboard cells be numbered A_k, where k goes from 0 (cell a8 in chess parlance) to 63 (cell h1 in chess parlance). K can be written in binary notation as k_5, k_4, ..., k_0. So, the chess cell b6 would be a_17, or written A_010001. To compute b_i, take the parity of the number of Heads in a set of A's chosen by selecting K's where in binary notation k_i is equal to 1. Thus, B_0 is the parity of all odd A's, that is simply the parity of all black cells of the board. B_1 is the parity of all pairs of cells starting with a8-b8, e8-f8, c7-d7, g7-h7, ..., g1-h1. B_2 the parity over all blocs of 4 cells starting with a8-d8, e7-h7, a6-d6, ... etc.

You will notice that by flipping A_k you change all B's where b_i is equal to 1 when k_i equals 1. So if you flip the chess cell b6, also known as A_010001, you will change the value of b_0 and of b_4 but not any other of the b's. If you flip the chess cell a8, the cell also known as A_000000, you don't change any of the B's, and that means that the board location was already telling you the location of the key. Since you can change any of the chess cells you can change any combination of the b_i's, and alter the number B at will to point at the correct key location.

How I got there, in a nutshell: i was looking for classes of board states that were accessible from any state by a single flip. That led me to solving the 2-cell board quite easily. The 4-cell board was harder, i solved it by visualizing a hypercube, each state being an apex, and flipping a one-step along a vertex. So I needed 4 sets of 4 apexes that were all reachable from any starting state. The hypercube can be visualized as a smaller normal cube nested inside a larger one, with corresponding corners connected. In this image it becomes evident that two corresponding corners of the twin cubes, plus their total opposites, make up a set of 4 reachable by a single vertex from any apex in the hypercube. The other 3 classes are obtained by starting at another corner on the base of the twin cubes. Once I had that solution I realized that the key location could also be described in terms of relationships between the digits of some indexes and that you could have a solution where a correct key location could be conserved by flipping A_00. If anyone is wondering, in the official solution there is no explicit strategy given for the generic N=2^n case, but they show that a strategy exists by proving that if a strategy exists for N=a and N=b, then there is a strategy for N=ab. (Here N is the number of squares and it is not important whether it is a square or just any natural number) Then one only has to get a strategy for two squares, which is trivial (and it is in the video).

The proof goes like this: if there is a strategy for N=a and N=b, one has a strategy for a squares and b squares, and given their H-T positions one can pinpoint one of the a or b squares, respectively, by just following the strategy, changing one of the squares.

I can consider then an a x b chessboard and we say a row is "head" if it has an even number of heads, and "tails" otherwise. This gives me a new problem with N=a "squares" (actually rows), and I can just change the type of one coin in a row to change the type of the entire row. This, thanks to the fact that a strategy with N=a squares exists, allows me to pick one row, switching the type of the corresponding row in the N=a strategy. There are b ways of doing this, one per column, as one can pick any coin on the row.

But at the same time, by symmetry, I can indicate one of the b columns, using the fact that a strategy for N=b exists, by changing an element in the appropriate column. But the element we choose can be on the row chosen previously, thus one can indicate to the other a row and a column at the same time, and thus one of the N=ab squares.

For those interested in this puzzle, this puzzle is also known as "The Devil's Chessboard." Of course there are multiple ways to attack this problem, but interestingly one solution you will find online also has a "computer science" flavor to it, similar to the error correction motivation as seen in this video. A possible solution to this puzzle is to label the the cells of the 8x8 board from 0 to 63 (we do this because we are putting our computer science hats on and start counting from 0). We then note the labels of each cell holding a coin with heads (or tails ... it doesn't matter) facing up. Convert each of those labels into its corresponding 6 bit integer (note that every cell on the board is in one to one correspondence with a binary string of length 6) and XOR all those integers ALONG WITH the label of the cell holding the secret key location. Now convert the result back into an integer which points to the cell holding the coin you should now flip. When your friend looks at the board, he/she will then (using the same labeling as you) XOR all the cells with heads facing up (or tail ... if that was what you used earlier). The final XOR result will be the cell location holding the key! For those not familiar with XORing two numbers, you basically need to line up the two 6-bit integers and look at each column where if you see two 1’s or two 0’s you write a 0 below and write 1 otherwise. Another interpretation is to write a 0 if the two bits are the same and write a 1 if the two bits are different. For example, 111000 XOR 010101 = 101101. You can play around with this strategy, by using a programming language. To XOR two numbers N and M you typically would need to type “N ^ M”.

 To see the connection to computer science, check out an encryption technique called a "One Time Pad." It works exactly through XORs similar to the solution of this puzzle. Let's say you want to encrypt a message, M, to send your friend, and supposed it is N bits long. For a secure encryption, you and your friend should generate a (uniformly) random N bit key, K, beforehand. Then to generate your ciphertext, C, you should compute C = K XOR M (or M XOR K because XOR is commutative which is fairly straightforward to verify). Then your friend would compute C XOR K (or K XOR C) to reveal the message M! The reason this works is because K XOR K always equals 0 for any choice of K (in technical terms K is called the "inverse" of K) and 0 XOR C always equals C for any choice of C (in technical terms 0 is called the “identity”). In addition to being commutative, XOR is also associative. If these properties sound very familiar, it is because it is! XOR sounds kinda like a special addition where negative numbers are just the numbers themselves! With this in mind, I’ll use “+” to denote XOR for brevity. Putting this all together, we know that C = K + M and that when revealing your message your friend will compute C + K = K + C = K + (K + M) = 0 + M = M!

 How does this relate to the Devil’s Chessboard? Well we can think of XORing all the cells with heads (I will ignore the situation where we use tails instead but the analysis is the same) as our “key” K and the key location being our message M. Formally, let K = X_1 + … + X_N where X_i is a cell with heads facing up and let M be the cell holding the key location. To generate our “ciphertext” which will be the cell holding the coin we flip, we perform as stated above C = K + M. The ingenuity of this solution lies in the fact that when your friend comes in and performs the XORing procedure stated above, he/she will compute C + K which as seen before will expose our message M! To see why this is case, note that either C will have been turned from tails to heads or turned from heads to tails. In the first case, your friend will see X_1, …, X_N, and C as heads and compute X_1 + … + X_N + C = K + C. In the second case, C will have flipped a coin that was previously heads (call this X_j), and your friend will then compute X_1 + … + X_(j-1) + X_(j+1) + … X_N = X_1 + … + X_(j-1) + 0 + X_(j+1) + … X_N = X_1 + … + X_(j-1) + (X_j + X_j) + X_(j+1) + … X_N = K + C. The second to last equality used the fact that X + X = 0 (mentioned above) and the last equality was due the commutative nature of XOR. As we see, no matter the case, your friend will ALWAYS compute K + C revealing the location of the key! 12:48 My solution to this was to look at closed loops of edges on the cube. Specifically, if your have an n-dimensional cube, and your colors are 1, 2, ..., n, then from any starting vertex you can always construct a path where the colors of each successive vertex loop through 1, 2, ..., n. This is because every node must be surrounded by all colors, so you can build the path step by step. The path will actually be a loop, since, for example, you can't have two 1's that are next to the same 2, so the path cannot enter any vertex it's already visited, except for the starting vertex. And eventually it will reach the starting vertex because there's only finitely many vertices. So by building these loops, we can fill up the entire vertex graph of the cube. And two loops cannot intersect for the same reason of no two 1's being next to the same 2. And the length of every loop must be some multiple of n, since each loop has to loop through all the colors an integer number of times before it gets back to 1. So that means that the total number or vertices is the sum of a bunch of lengths that are multiples of n. So the number of vertices must itself be a multiple of n. Yet it must also be 2^n. It can then be shown using prime factorization that 2^n is only a multiple of n if n is a power of 2. This shows that there's only a solution if n is a power of 2.

Now, another argument I thought of is the following. Every vertex sees 1 red vertex around it. And every red vertex sees 3 vertices. Now, whenever a vertex sees a red vertex, that red vertex sees the other vertex too. This means that the number of times a vertex sees a red vertex is equal to the number of times a red vertex sees a vertex. Let's call that number E. Then E is 1 times the number of vertices, and 3 times the number of red vertices. That means there must 3 times as many vertices as there are red vertices. So 1/3 of the vertices is red. The same reasoning applies to any other n besides 3.

Alternative way to phrase "each colour must occur the same number of times": pick any two colours, say red and blue. Define a function f from red vertices to blue ones such that f(v) is the unique blue neighbour of v. It's an easy check this is a bijection (that is, every blue vertex lies in the image exactly once) - so there must be equally many red and blue vertices.

Here there is my reasoning for solving this problem (before watching the video). I thought about a simplified version of the problem: a 2x2 grid in which tails are 0s and heads are 1s. This means that every initial and final configuration is a binary number. But this doesn't bring me anywhere. So I start to write tables of what happened if, starting from different setup, I will flip a coin. I obtain 4 different binary numbers with nothing in common. After a trial and error procedure, I see that if I associate a different weight to each position (position 1 has weight 1, position 2 has weight 2 and so on), I obtain always different numbers. In particular, if I take the mod4 of that number (4 is the maximum number of cell present) I always obtain a number between 0 and 3 that is exactly what I'm looking for. But why does this happen? Let's call a, b, c, d the variables in the first, second, third, and fourth position. Those variables can assume only the 0 or 1 value. The final number obtained in this way is mod4(4*a + 3*b + 2*c + d). Now if I want to change my initial number by 1, I change the d coin, if I want to change my initial number by 2 I change the c coin and so on... This because each letter has a different weight that corresponds exactly to how much I want that number to change. (Having only watched the first few minutes) I paused the video and found a solution that would work 75% of the time if the warden was replaced by a random robot. Assign each square on the board a number ranging from 0 to 63 uniquely, for our purposes organised neatly going across then down from 0 to 63. When you see the board, if the coin on a square is heads, add it to a total, if it's tails, add nothing to the total. Then take the total and calculate the remainder on division by 64. This is a property of the grid, and will be in the range 0-63. Therefore you could target a particular square using this property. Now you need to flip a coin to change this property and make it point to the desired square. Say the property of the grid when you saw it was 3 and the square selected by the robot had been given the value 7. You have two options to change the property: either you add 4, to make it seven, or you subtract 60 (based on the properties of remainders, 3-60 _= -57 + 64 _= 7 (64). Now, hope that either the square with the value 4 is left on tails, in which case you can flip it over, adding four to the total and making it 7, or hope that the square with the value 60 is left on heads, in which case flip it over, subtracting 60 from the total and pointing to 7.
When the warden is replaced by a random robot, each of these events is 50% likely, so 75% at least one or both. However this strategy totally fails in the case of an antagonistic warden, as they can easily choose a setup where neither of the two flipping options is available.
